posts.cooked:
we’re having some issues with setting up swerve with yagsl. we’ve put in all the offsets and i know the readings are correct, however when we push the joystick it tries to set the raw encoder value to the angle setpoint? here are the values from shuffleboard image 1722×1143 107 KB

image 1722×1143 107 KB

image 1722×1143 107 KB

posts.name: Andrii Bessarab
posts.cooked:
Hey there!

It’s hard to pinpoint the exact issue from the Shuffleboard values alone. When I ran into issues with angle motors, I found FRC Web Components very helpful. It visualizes desired vs. acquired states, and it was instrumental in identifying and correcting inversions, which ultimately fixed our drive. Perhaps, give it a shot!

Also, I don’t know your swerve config, but perhaps you need to add swervedrive.pushOffsetsToControllers() to the constructor?

And lastly, have you set the gear ratio and conversion factors correctly?
adding swervedrive.pushOffsetsToControllers() causes the modules to spin uncontrollably. yes, the gear ratios and conversion factors are correct.

posts.name: Andrii Bessarab
posts.cooked: If it spins out of control, that could well indicate that either an absolute or relative encoder isn’t inverted correctly.
sorry, it doesnt spin uncontrollably. it actually does nothing.

posts.name: Andrii Bessarab
posts.cooked: If you get a chance, send a screenshot or two from Web Components (or if you have AdvantageScope set up) as that might give a better understanding of what is happening.

image 2880×1624 448 KB here you go!

image 2880×1624 448 KB

image 2880×1624 448 KB

posts.name: Andrii Bessarab
posts.cooked:
It seems that the angle value for neither FL motor nor BR motor match what measuredState shows. Do you mind expanding what measuredStates are as well as showing data for other modules.

A few other things:

Is your YAGSL up-to-date?—they had a version where azimuth motors would spin past desired states.

When you point your joystick in that direction, do the motors always end up in the same(or complementary) positions?

Is what shown in Advantage actually matches the physical position of the wheels?

Did you check that when you spin the wheel CCW both abs encoder and rel encoder values increase as well as in the Advantage—the wheel rotates ccw?

YAGSL is up to date, yes. the motors do always end up in the same position. advantage does not seem close to what is actually going on with the robot no the values do increase yes

posts.name: Andrii Bessarab
posts.cooked:
That is quite strange!

To clarify, when you say wheels end up in the same position, do you mean on the actual robot or in Advantage(because if I understood it right—those do not match)?

Do you mind listing your drive’s specifications, sort of like:

Modules: MK4i L2

Motors: Neo V1.1

Motor Controllers: Spark MAX

Absolute Encoders: CanCoder

IMU: Pigeon 2

And also do you have your code on some kind of remote VCS so i could view it?

posts.name: Andrii Bessarab
posts.cooked:
I looked at the code. Let me know if I’m misunderstanding it.

The command that runs by default is drivebase.setDefaultCommand(driveRobotOrientedAngularVelocity) .

But on the line Command driveRobotOrientedAngularVelocity  = drivebase.driveFieldOriented(driveRobotOriented) you are using a field oriented command which “Drives the robot given a chassis field oriented velocity.” , but it seems you provide it with robot-oriented velocity instead?

In Advantage, if you are—in fact—driving field-oriented, in addition to desired states and measured states, you should feed it rotation (from the images above, it does not seem like it’s there).

In SwerveSubsystem, there is a method:

Maybe, try using that or one of other drive commands instead. Here is the command my team used.
it works somewhat better in field oriented but it’s still off? somehow? how would be drive robot oriented though? because the command we were using was just there by default.

posts.name: Andrii Bessarab
posts.cooked:
Try creating a command similar to ours:

And in RobotContainer:

The three suppliers are values from the controller in the range of -1 to 1 of three different axes, i.e., fwd, left, and ccw.

Try that and let me know if it helps!

They are using a custom swerve module with a gear ratio on the absolute encoder. Ontop of this the support for SRX Mag’s isnt very well fleshed out due to the lack of a userbase. We just debugged their problem in the YAGSL discord.

Their fixes were applied to a local copy in their code which does the following

Applies a gear ratio to TalonSRXEncoderSwerve conversion factor.

Fixes TalonSRXSwerve.setAbsoluteEncoder to set the boolean value based on the passed in absolute encoder type. (Upstreamed)

Call SwerveDrive.useExternalFeedbackSensor to force the offset from the absolute encoder into the TalonSRX encoder offset as it appeared that the offset was not taken into account correctly without this.
